div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7189] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, MAY 4, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Suez about May 4 | R.M.S "Ortona" will leave Suez about May 19.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Omrah" will leave Port Said about May 10 | R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said about May 24.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: No change in the weather. Moderate northerly breeze, slight sea, fine and clear throughout. Barometer falling.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: TROUBLES IN RUSSIA. FURTHER SERIOUS RIOTS. NUMEROUS VICTIMS.
div.p: The number of killed yesterday was 62 and the wounded probably nearly 200. The anxiety regaining to-day is increasing. The Nationalists have arranged the usual demonstrations. The working men are in an ugly and uncertain mood. The workmen at all the factories have struck. (Reuter.)
The Polish patriotic demonstration here this afternoon was dispersed by the Cossacks. Monday’s victims will be buried secretly to- night. (Reuter.)
Further serious riots have taken place yesterday, the troops fired int. the crowd, killing and wounding many. Fighting is reported at Grodno, where there is a general strike of the workmen. (Reuter.)
The number of deaths the day before yester- day was 62 and of wounded 200. (Havas.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. NOT IN FRENCH WATERS.
div.p: In reply to an informal representation of the Japanese Legation last Monday, the French Foreign Office intimated that it believed all Russian vessels had quitted French waters. (Reuter.)
M. Motono, Japanese Minister, asked Ministry for Foreign Affairs whether the Rus- sian squadron was still in French waters. He received a reply in the negative. (Havas.)

div.head: PORT ARTHUR. SALVAGE OPERATIONS ON SHIPS.
div.p: The salvage operations on Russian men-of- war sunk at Port Arthur are progressing satis- factorily. It is believed that several battleships and cruisers can be secured. (Reuter.)

div.head: CHINAS NEUTRALITY. NOTE FROM GREAT BRITAIN.
div.p: The "Morning Post" learns from Washington that Great Britain has addressed a note warn- ing China in identical terms to that of the United States, impressing on the Government the necessity for a strict neutrality. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCE AND THE U.S.A. A NOTABLE EVENT.
div.p: General McCormick, the new American Am- bassador to France, when presenting his cre- dentials to President Loubet, said that he re- joiced at the development of the ideas which led to the rapprochement of France and the Mother Country of Americans. An allusion of this character by an Ambassador on such an an occasion is most unusual, and it is regarded as the weightiest expression of American feeling. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE ALIENS BILL. READ FOR SECOND TIME.
div.p: House of Commons-The Aliens Bill has been read for the second time by 211 votes to 50. M. Baltour declared: “We are amply justified in determining the conditions under which we would or would not admit the citizens of other nations.” (Reuter.)

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON LATE PLANTING
div.p: Exhaustive private investigation shows that cotton planting in the United States is a fort- night later than usual. The average plantation is reduced by 10% and less is being expended on fertilisers. The low temperatures have been unfavorable. (Reuter.)

div.head: NEWMARKET RACES. THE TWO THOUSAND GUINEAS.
KING OF SAXONY IN VIENNA.
div.p: The King of Saxony is on a visit to the Emperor. (Havas.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Mena House Hotel will close for the season on Monday next, 8th inst.
The P.&O. mail steamer “Isis” arrived at Alexandria from Port Said this morning in order to be drydocked.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Zeitoun district at dawn to-morrow will be poisoned by the police.
Popular University. — M. George Blum will lecture at the university on Saturday at 9.15 p.m. on “La Massiere" by Jules Lemaltre.
Sanitary Dept.-M. Khalil Haddad has been authorised to practise as pharmacist, and Messrs. Panayotti G. Sakellariou and Socrate Lagoudakis as physicians.
A. S. C.—The second day of the Alexandria Sporting Club's first Summer Meeting pro- mises to be a great success. The Khedive has announced his intention of honoring the races with his presence.

St. George's Day.—There will be high mass and a “Te Deum" will be sung at the Greek- Orthodox Cathedral on Saturday next, as it is St. George's Day in the Orthodox calendar and the name day of the King of the Hellenes.

Suez Canal.—16 vessels passed through the Canal on the 28th and 29th ulto., 10 of which were British, 3 French, 2 German, 1 Norwegian. The receipts for the two days were frs. 457,200.80 and for the month of April frs. 9,865,804.94.

Esbekieh Theatre.- The Italian theatrical company under the direction of Sig. Giuseppe Gray will give its first performance on the 15th or 16th inst. at the Esbekieh Garden Theatre. Le Maitre des Forges will be the first piece given, with Lucrezia Borgia, a one-act vaudeville.

Egypt and Palestine. — Some important traces of the old connection between Egypt and Palestine are discussed in the annual report of the Palestine Exploration Fund on the subject of the Gaza explorations. Last year an important discovery was made there of scarabs and scarab seals, including many of the Hyksos period and a scarab of Amenhotep III and his Queen. There were also other dis- coveries all tending to show the close, connec- tion between Palestine and Egypt in the time of the Hyksos (Shepherd Kings.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Moha- med Zeky Pasha, uncle of the President of the Council of Ministers, Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, which occurred yesterday at Cairo.

Boghos Pasha Nubar leaves Egypt for Rome on the 29th inst. to represent the Khedivial Government at the International Agricultural Congress, which will hold its first meeting on the 28th inst. under the presidency of H. M. the King of Italy.

M. Miltiades Papadakis, judge in the Tri- bunal of 1st Instance at Sparta, will probably be appointed president of the Hellenic Con- sular Court at Alexandria, in succession to M. Dimaras, who has been made Greek Con- sul at Adrianople.
We hear that there will be dancing at Mrs. Chataway's garden party to-morrow afternoon at Nouzha Gardens.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Riyage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr. and Mrs. R. May, Captain and Mrs. W. H. Rotheram, Mr. and Mrs. L. Davis, Mrs. A. Miller and family, Mr.J. W. Dart, Mr. and E. Tisseau, Mr. and Mrs. Basile I Calouta, Mr. and Mrs. F. Burley, Mrs. J. H. Farrar and courier, the Misses Farrar, Miss Lewis Stewart, Miss M. Young, Miss L. Wormer, Mr. aud Mrs. E. Herbert, Mr. R. Ahrab, Miss T. H. Bird, Miss M. Soulie, Miss A. Mason, and Mr. and Mrs. J.E. Marshall and family.

div.head: OBITUARY. MAITRE PAUL RUELENS.
div.p: We deeply regret to announce the death of Maitre Paul Ruelens, the well-known Belgian- barrister of the Mixed Court of Appeal at Alexandria. The deceased had to relinquish a large and lucrative practice at the Bar in December, 1903, owing to dropsy. The malady confined him to his house for the past seventeen months. About three weeks ago he became dangerously ill and succumbed yes- terday afternoon.

Maitre Reulens was born on March 14, 1849, at Brussels, where his father held the post of chief librarian to the Belgian National Library. He was educated at the University of Brussels and was called to the Bar there in 1872. In 1885 he came out to Egypt, where he soon obtained an excellent legal practice. He had a profound knowledge of law and was a very clever advocate, being often appealed to by bis follow barristers for advice on difficult points of law. He was very popular in his own profession, and his geniality and goodness of heart endeared him to a large circle of friends.
We beg to tender our sincere sympathies to his widow and only son; M. Charles Ruelens, in their bereavement. The funeral took place this morning.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE. ARRIVAL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive left Cairo at 7.45 o'clock this morning for Alexandria. Guards of honor chosen from the Egyptian Army and the Army of Occupation were present at the station to pay the usual honors, and the Railway Ad- ministration had taken great pains to decorate the interior and exterior of the station build- ings with excellent results. A great number of prominent officials and notables, with many re- presentatives of the Press, were present, besides all the Ministers, the Advisers and Under Secretaries of State, heads of departments, etc.

His Highness arrived at the station from Koubbeh by special train shortly after half- past seven and immediately left the train, standing for some time on the platform, convers- ing with the Ministers and Advisers, and many of the notables present.

The guards of honor were drawn up within the station, the Inniskillings on one platform and the Egyptian troops on the other, and the Khedivial salute was given as his Highness entered and left the station, a salute of 21 guns being fired from the Citadel as the train steamed out.

Major Blakeney, R.E., and Messrs. Cotterill, Peacock, and Trevithick travelled in the Khedivial train, which arrived at the Mohar- rem Bey terminus punctually to the minute at 11.30 o'clock, and a salute of 21 guns from Kom el Dik announced the arrival of the train. The station had been very tastefully decorated in honor of the occasion and there was a beautiful display of shrubs and bunting. A large and representative gathering of Euro- pean and native notables were assembled on the platform to greet his Highness, who on detraining, walked up the platform, cordially shaking many of those present by the hand.

Outside the station a guard of honor of Egyptian troops, composed of 100 non-commis- sioned officers aud men, the battalion colour, and the Infantry band, was paraded, and a similar guard of honor from the British garrison was also paraded.

The Khedive, on leaving the station,inspect- ed the two guards of honor and then drove off to Ras-el-Tin Palace, escorted by his body guard. The streets on the line of route to the Palace were gaily decorated with flags and bunting, and Cherif Pasha-street presented a most animated appearance.
The Khedive was accompanied by his Ministers and the members of his household.
H.H. the Khedivah left Cairo at 8 a.m. for Montazah, where her Highness arrived at 12.15 p.m.
H.H. the Khedive has promised Sayed el- Bakri that he will attend the religious cere- mony to be held at Abbassieh on the birthday of the Prophet.
After the close of Tuesday’s reception H.H. the Khedive gave audience to M. Toussaint Caueri, who presented his Highness with a copy of his essay on the establishment of a municipality at Cairo.

H.H. the Khedive has conferred the 3rd class of the order of tho Osmanieh on M.B. Moritz, director of the Khedivial Library, and the 4th class of the same order on El Said al Mohamed Ali el Biblaoui, sub-director.
The following is the order in which visitors will be received at the Khedivial reception to be held at Ras-el-Tin Palace on Saturday next:—
At 9 a.m.— T.H. the Princes of the Khe- divial Family; the Ulema; the heads of State Administrations.
At 9.30 a.m.— The Mixed Magistracy; the Native Magistracy; naval and army officers of the rank of Bimbashi and upwards; civil officials.

At 10 a.m.— Unofficial military and civil personages having the rank of Lewa or Oula Sinf Sani and upwards, naval and army officers unattached and on the retired list having the rank of Kaimakam or Miralai; unofficial civil Beys having the rank of Sanieh and upwards; the Municipal Com- mission.
At 10.30 a.m.— The Diplomatic and Consu- lar Corps.
At 10.45 a.m.— Field officers of the Army of Occupation; the clergy.
At 11 a.m.- Native notables; European notables.
This reception is reserved to persons resid- ing in Alexandria.
The military will attend in undress uniform and civilians in frock coats (redingote).

The civil officials admitted to this reception are those having at least the rank of sub director or an equivalent rank, and those having at least the grade of Sanieh or of it Kaimakam (military), and the magistrates ap- pointed by decree.

The Khedivah will also hold a reception at the Palace on Saturday. Tho Princesses of the Khedivial Family and native ladies will be received from 10 to 11.30 a.m., and European ladies from 4 to 5 p.m.

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE NOTES. PRINCE MOHAMED ALY.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).

H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly, brother of H.H. the Khedive, went on Friday last to Yildiz Kiosk, to attend the ceremony of the Selamlik. On this occasion, the Sultan was pleased to bestow on him the plaque en brillants of the “Iftihar.” His Highness has also been promoted to the rank of marshal in the Ottoman Army.
Izzet Bey, secretary for the Khedive’s Turk- bureau, has received the Grand Cordon of the Osmanieh, and Mansur Sidki Bey, private secretary of Prince Mohamed Aly, the third class of the Medjidieh.
Prince Mohamed Aly paid a visit on Tuesday last to M. Constans, French Am- bassador at Constantinople. His Highness left yesterday by the Orient express for Vienna and Paris.

div.head: M. MAXIMOFF’S SUCCESSOR.
div.p: M. Smirnoff, the newly-appointed Russian Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, arrived here last Df J*1 week on his way to take up his new post. Before his departure, he had an interview with M. Zinowien, Russian Ambassador here. M. Maximoff, formerly Russian Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, who has been appointed Minister at Cettigne, is already here. After a stay of a few weeks in our city, he will leave for St. Peters- burg, whence he will proceed to Montenegro.

div.head: RUSSIAN STEAMSHIP COMPANY.
div.p: There have been some changes in the steam- ship companies in our town. M. Coïdan has been appointed assistant agent of the Russian Company at Alexandria. He has already left for his new post. M. A. Petropoulo, assistant agent at Alexandria, has been appointed as such here, and is expected to arrive shortly.

div.head: RUSSIAN REFUGEES AT SUEZ.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).

The S.S. "Swanley,” chartered by the Rus- sian Government, arrived at Suez yesterday evening at 7 o'clock from Shanghai with 1,107 Russian refugees on board. The vessel entered the Canal late last night bound to Odessa.

div.head: LORD MILNER AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: Lord Milner returned to Cairo from Assouan early this morning and will arrive at Alexan- dria this evening.

div.head: THE HOLY CARPET.
div.p: The Holy Carpet will have purged its qua- rantine at Tor on Monday next. It will arrive at Suez the following day and at Cairo on Wednesday. The ceremony of the return of the Mahmal will take place at Cairo on Thurs- day, 11th inst. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy will represent the Khedive.
The following version of the recent trouble appears in “Al Lewa," which declares that it received it from a good source :—

When the pilgrims reached a station called “Al Kamra," on the morning of the day in question, the soldiers went to the market, which contains 700 Bedouins, all well armed. One of the soldiers bought a packet of tobacco from a Bedouin but would not give him the price asked for. The Bedouin hesitated to give the soldier the packet of tobacco, and the latter thereupon became irritated, and gave the Bedouin a blow which threw him to the ground. The Bedouin got up and gave the soldier a beating which injured him severely. Afterwards the Bedouins took up a position behind the hills, and firing ensued between the two sides for two hours. The losses were 26 soldiers injured, 4 killed, and 10 pilgrims, 6 horses, and 12 camels killed. Ten or twelve Bedouins were injured.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: The following is the result of yesterday’s regatta.
The wind was moderate from the N. W. during the greater part of the afternoon. The "Minnie" unfortunately carried away her bob stay and bowsprit and therefore gave up.

The sea outside was very moderate and no doubt in Class II. the “Lanrea" would have come in first if she had not been beset with a chapter of accidents, such as carrying away her main sheet, top mast stay, and throat halyards, and eventually her topmast broke off altogether. However, she carried on and after clearing away all the wreckage managed to get second place.

div.head: MOHAMED ALY MEMORIAL. THE MADHOUSE SCHEME.
div.p: A correspondent writes :—

"The idea of celebrating the centenary of the founder of the Khedivial Dynasty, and of a man who was undoubtedly one of the great figures of history during the past century, by the construction of a madhouse, is decidedly original, and the originator of the scheme deserves to be warmly congratulated on his sense of humour. It is stated by the advocates of the project that speculation is so much on the increase at Alexandria, and has taken such a strong hold on all classes, that if a crash did come, the existing accommodation for the insane in the Government Hospital, would be ridiculously small to accommodate the vast number of lunatics who would be thrown upon the town.

"The prospect is not a pleasing one to con- template, and it is sincerely to be hoped that the awful eventuality may not come to pass. But even if a crash were likely to fill the streets with crowds of maddened speculators, I fail to see that there is any necessity for such an inappropriate memorial to the great Pasha as a madhouse. The Government is considering the construction of a large lunatic asylum; plans are now being prepared, and although the site has not yet been chosen, it will in all probability be situated somewhere between Alexandria and Cairo. Why then should Alexandrians go out of their way to subscribe for an institution which ought to be undertaken by the Government, and when we know that the foundation of such an asylum is now under consideration by the Government? In memorials, dependent on public subscript- tions, it is one of the essentials of success that the object for which the subscribers’ donations are asked should strike the imagination to a certain degree and also be appropriate, quâ memorial, to the man in whose honor it is erected. Why then a madhouse? Surely many other far more attractive memorials could be found, such for instance as a public library?”

div.head: IRISH DINNER AT CAIRO.
div.p: An "Irish dinner" was held on Tuesday night at Shepheard’s Hotel and was a great success in every way, the arrangements, decora- tions, and menu being greatly appreciated by all who were present. The chair was taken by Johnson Pasha, and among the Irishmen who took part in the dinner were Dr. Keatinge, Mr. Verschoyle, Col. Atkinson, Major Donegan, Mr. Adams, Mr. Stokes, Mr. Macloughlin, Mr. Langley, Mr. Weldon (to whose excellent arrangements much of the success of the evening was due), Mr. Villiers-Stuart, Mr. Young, Mr. O'Sullivan, and many others.

After the usual loyal and patriotic toasts had been honored, speeches were delivered by the chairman and a large proportion of the Irishmen present, and were received with un- animous applause. It was decided to form an Irish Dinner Club, which should meet every St Patrick's Day, and all present bound them- selves to spare no pains to obtain Irish recruits. Mr. Langley was elected nem. con. to the pre- sidency of the club, Mr. Weldon being un- animously chosen as secretary.

The communicative glow which illumined the banquet was so dazzling as to make any account of the many speeches delivered a difficult task. The toast of "Ireland" was received with immense enthusiasm, and, speech- es over, music of a thoroughly national character followed. Among the many excellent songs, a topical version of “Peace, Peace," by Major Donegan, made a great hit, while Mr. Adams proved in excellent voice, and the party did not break up till long after midnight. The thanks of all present are due to the band of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, whose programme included a large number of national and patriotic airs which were admirably ren- dered.

div.head: PORT SAID SALT ASSOCIATION.
div.p: In reference to the report of the Port Said Salt Association, which was published in yes- terday’s issue of the "Gazette," we may men- tion that an issue of 92,500 ten shilling shares will shortly take place at the rate of 12s 6d. per share. The object of this increase of capital is to enable the company to fit up the Port Said salt works with all the latest 1 31, machinery and appliances for the extraction la q and refinement of salt The old shareholders denx have already subscribed a portion of the capital, which has been reserved for them, and the balance will be offered to the public. This balance has already been covered by a syndicate of guarantors.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Congo” arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria at 5 a.m. yesterday.
The S.S. "City of Cambridge” will leave for Liverpool on the 10th inst.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Cette dernière quinzaine a été entravée par les fêtes de Pâques et peut-être faut-il s’en féliciter, car bien des positions déjà embaras- sées n’auraient pas manqué do se surcharger encore si la salutaire inaction des vacances n’était venue à point paralyser les transactions. Malgré cet arrêt opportun des affaires, les liquidations de fin du mois ont été excessive- ment laborieuses, pour ne pas dire désastreu- ses. Certains agents laissent vraiment trop de latitude à leurs remisiers et se contentent de marges par trop insuffisantes, de telle sorte qu’à l’échéance leurs clients n’ayant pas les moyens de prendre livraison des titres qu’ils ont achetés se voient contraints de liquider à n’im- porte quel prix. Les ventes qui en résultent mettent évidemment les acheteurs en éveil et ceux-ci toujours à l’affût des bonnes occasions aident à casser les cours pour acheter ensuite à meilleur compte.

Le retard apporté au règlement des nou- velles émissions pèse lourdement sur le marché et constitue une des principales causes de la faiblesse actuelle. On a pu voir, en effet, que les positions fin de mois en actions de premier ordre étaient normales, ce qui a maintenu pour ces valeurs une fermeté relative. Ce sont les titres nouvellement émis qui ayant exercé sur là spéculation une fascination malsaine l’ont entrainée hors de toute limite. De petits capitalistes, comptant que les titres en question ne pourraient être livrés que dans un laps de temps considérable, se sont imprudemment engagés et, l’événement ayant devancé leurs prévisions, ont dû liquider avec des pertes énormes. Cette - rapidité dans l’arrivée des titres de l’Investment dont il convient de féli- citer ici les promoteurs et l'Anglo Egyptian Bank a donc été pour les imprévoyants une désagréable surprise.

Maintenant le gros de l’orage est passé; réalisations et liquidations pourront bien con- tinuer encore quelques jours, mais les positions se trouvant allégées, les cours ne tarderont pas à reprendre. Espérons, pour que de pareilles liquidations ne se roproduisent pas, qu'on se modèrera désormais en affaires à terme et que les titres en suspens, tels que les Estates, les Trust et les General Trust seront bientôt réglés. Jusque-là un nuage ne cessera de planer sur notre place qui ne pourra vraiment reprendre son essor qu'une fois dégagée de toutes ces en- traves. Il faut s'attendre, sans doute, à un nouveau recul à l’arrivée des titres; beaucoup d'imprévoyants se trouveront sacrifiés; mais il n’y a pas d’autres moyens d’assainir la place.

Comme si tous ces désagréments ne suffi- saient pas, nombre d’agences de deuxième ordre se font tirer l'oreille pour le rdglement de leurs affaires et ce sont les agences vrai- ment sérieuses qui doivent en supporter les con- séquences. Aussi beaucoup de maisons de cour- tage réclament-elles instamment un "Clearing House” sur le modèle de celui qui déjà fono- tionne au Caire. On objecte, il est vrai, que les courtiers du Caire ont tous un capital déclaré, tandis que plus d’un tiers de ceux d'Alex- andrie n’ayant pas ou presque pas de capital, auraient des difficultés incessantes avec le Clearing House; mais cette objection même milite en faveur de l’adoption du système. La place d'Alexandrie ne peut que gagner à un petit nettoyage et le nouveau comité de l’As- sociation des courtiers en valeurs l’a si bien compris qu’il prépare un règlement pour mettre los choses au point.
Les valeurs qui ont donné lieu aux plus forts mouvements pendant cette quinzaine sont l’Agricole, la Daïra, la Salt & Soda et l’Invest- ment.
En Agricole les transactions sont toujours importantes. On ouvre à 13 3/8 et touche 13 5/8 pour finir à 13 1/2.
En Daïra le cours monte de 27 15/16 à 29 9/16, mais de fortes réalisations ramènent la valeur à 28 13/16. De son côté la Part de Fondateur monte de 164 £ à 180 pour re- tomber en clôture à 174.

On a échangé journellement des milliers de Salt & Soda. De nombreuses positions sur- chargées liquident et las capitalistes profitent de la baisse qui en résulte pour garnir leurs portefeuilles. On débute à 39, fléchit à 34/6 et clôture à 35. On a beaucoup parlé d’un cou- pon médiocre et du prochain établissement en Egypte, à Zagarig et à Mansourah, d’une so- ciété anglaise d’Huileries et Savonneries, mais aucune de ces nouvelles n’est encore con- firmée.

De 2 3/16 l’Investment fléchit graduellement jusqu’à 1 13/16 pour reprendre en clôture à 1 31/32 scheteurs. On a échangé durant toute la quinzaine d’énormes paquets de titres. Les deux procès, intentés contre The Egyptian Investment et Agency Limited en palement de dommages intérêts, par des personnes mé- contentes de la répartition des actions émises par la dite société ce non favorisées par elle, ont été jugés mardi par la Chambre Commerciale du Tribunal. La société avait soulevé une ex- ception d’irrecevabilité de l’instance introduite par les dites personnes, ayant déclaré que cette instance devait être dirigée personnelle- ment contre les directeurs à Londres auxquels les souscripteurs s’étaient adressés et qui ont procédé à la répartition. Elle a en outre conclu au fond an rejet de la demande. Le Tribunal a déclaré recevable l’instance dont a’agit, ayant estimé que les actes des directeurs on adminis- trateurs ont engagé la Société, puisqu’ils ont été faits dans son intérêt; mais il a rejeté la demande au fond, ayant déclaré que la dite Société est régie par les lois anglaises; que ces lois et notamment la dernière dénommée "The Companies Act 1900" n’ont pas été violées, puisqu’elles accordent aux directeurs et ad- ministrateurs une liberté complète dans l’at- tribution des actions; que la Société a agi dans la plénitude de ses droits en faisant la répartition des actions comme elle l’a entendu et que les termes du prospectus et de la de- mande adressée par les souscripteurs réservent effectivement, pourqui est au courant des moeurs anglaises, aux directeurs de cette Société une liberté complète dans l’attribution des actions.

row.cell: Tot. returns for current year date

div.head: The Standard Life Assurance Company.
div.p: Established 1825.
Accumulated Funds £11,300,000
Bonus Year, 1905.
The next division of profits will be made amongst participating Policies in existence at 15th November 1905.
All With Profit Policies effected on or before that date will be entitled to share in the Division.
The Company have already declared Bonus Additions to Policies to the amount of more than Seven Million Sterling.
Head Office for Egypt: Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo.
B. Nathan & Cl, Chief Agents for Alexandria.
A. V. Thomson, Secretary for Egypt.

div.head: CEREAL MARKET
div.p: ROD EL FARAG (National Bank’s Shoonah)
